user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_to_uint64_n_:
```c
size_t
MHD_str_to_uint64_n_ (const char *str,
                      size_t maxlen,
                      uint64_t *out_val)
{
  uint64_t res;
  size_t i;

  if (! str || ! maxlen || ! out_val || ! isasciidigit (str[0]))
    return 0;

  res = 0;
  i = 0;
  do
  {
    const int digit = (unsigned char) str[i] - '0';

    if ( (res > (UINT64_MAX / 10)) ||
         ( (res == (UINT64_MAX / 10)) &&
           ((uint64_t) digit > (UINT64_MAX % 10)) ) )
      return 0;

    res *= 10;
    res += (unsigned int) digit;
    i++;
  } while ( (i < maxlen) &&
            isasciidigit (str[i]) );

  *out_val = res;
  return i;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_str_to_uint64_n_:
_MHD_static_inline bool
isasciidigit (char c)
{
  return (c >= '0') && (c <= '9');
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: MISRA C:2023 Rule 21.14 forbids using the Standard Library function memcmp to compare null-terminated strings. The provided target function and the related isasciidigit implementation contain no calls to memcmp, no wrapper/alias of memcmp, and no other bulk memory comparison operations that could be interpreted as using memcmp. All character tests are performed via single-character comparisons (e.g. isasciidigit uses c >= '0' && c <= '9'), and the code parses digits and performs arithmetic—there are no string-to-string comparisons of null-terminated strings. Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that need to be investigated for Rule 21.14.
